question: how a care giver can deal with a mental client

clueweb22-en0021-88-06208.point_content: Family caregivers can sometimes feel “swallowed up” by the ongoing demands of the caregiving role and caregiver responsibilities. With reflection and focus on the strengths and capabilities you bring to this role, you can take greater control over your experiences, feel more competent, enhance your well-being, and ultimately, be a happier person.
spans: Family caregivers can sometimes feel “swallowed up” by the ongoing demands of the caregiving role and caregiver responsibilities.

With reflection and focus on the strengths and capabilities you bring to this role, you can: Take greater control over your experiences Feel more competent Enhance your well-being And ultimately, be a happier person

clueweb22-en0021-88-06208.point_content: Identifying and being aware of your caregiver strengths will serve both you and the person you’re caring for. Once you recognize the internal resources you already have, you can develop an action plan to utilize these resources to counteract difficulties and challenges you face in the context of caregiving.
spans: Identifying and being aware of your caregiver strengths will serve both you and the person you’re caring for.
Once you recognize the internal resources you already have, you can develop an action plan to utilize these resources to counteract difficulties and challenges you face in the context of caregiving.

clueweb22-en0021-88-06208.point_content: Caregiver strengths include resilience, patience, flexibility, compassion, optimism, confidence, organization, and ability to laugh, which are applicable to the caregiving experience and can help in dealing with challenges.
spans: Caregiver Strengths Resilience – The ability to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions; I can negotiate for what I need and navigate systems. Patience – The capacity to accept or tolerate delay, trouble, or suffering without getting angry or upset. Flexibility – Ready and able to change so as to adapt to different circumstances; accept what is happening in the moment. Compassion – The ability to translate empathic feelings into action (desire to alleviate suffering). Optimism – Expect a favourable or positive outcome. Confidence – Sure of one’s self and one’s abilities. Organization – Methodical and efficient in arrangement or function. Ability to Laugh – To easily see and appreciate the humour in the situation.

clueweb22-en0021-88-06208.point_content: To identify your caregiver strengths, reflect on what gives you energy, what you do well, your best character traits, and how you handle challenges, or ask someone who knows you well for their perspective.
spans: Caregiver Strengths Exercise #1 To identify and acknowledge your personal caregiver strengths, set aside a few minutes for personal reflection. Ask yourself the following questions: What gives me energy? What am I good at? What do I do best? What do I do well? What am I naturally good at? What comes naturally to me? What are my best character traits? What things do I look forward to doing? When faced with challenges or adversity, what strengths do I bring to these challenges? What do I handle well?
If you find it difficult to assess your caregiver strengths, ask your best friend or someone who knows you well to answer these questions about you.

clueweb22-en0021-88-06208.point_content: Harness your caregiver strengths by consciously applying them to your caregiving activities, managing challenges by limiting, delegating, or nurturing them, and setting goals to leverage strengths or develop weaknesses.
spans: Harnessing your caregiver strengths Now that you have identified and acknowledged your personal caregiver strengths you can decide to consciously approach your caregiving by harnessing these strengths and applying them to your family caregiving experiences and activities.
Conversely, what has likely emerged is a conscious understanding of what your greatest challenges are and where you are not at your best.

It is equally important to have this awareness because you can develop a caregiver action plan to manage these challenges. Try to limit them to the bare minimum, delegate them to someone else for whom they are strengths, and/or make a decision and plan to nurture and enhance your challenges.

How are you going to harness your caregiver strengths? Look at your list of personal strengths. How can you draw upon and really leverage your strengths more as a family caregiver? If possible, can you change anything in your caregiving situation to work more with your strengths? Can you delegate tasks that don’t align with your strengths? On the other hand, are there opportunities for you to work on and strengthen any weaknesses? Is there a trait that really matters to you? Is this an opportunity to set an intention for yourself for the next week? Identify one goal to either leverage a strength more or to further develop and overcome a weakness. Observe any changes that occur when you intentionally put your caregiver strengths into action.

clueweb22-en0017-75-09634.point_content: Caregivers have significantly higher rates of physical illness, depression and even mortality compared to noncaregivers, which in turn reduces their ability to provide quality care.
spans: These caregivers have significantly higher rates of physical illness, depression and even mortality compared to noncaregivers, which in turn reduces their ability to provide quality care.

clueweb22-en0017-75-09634.point_content: Caregivers should not blame themselves for an illness they cannot control and should seek support and self-care.
spans: it's crucial that you, the caregiver, not blame yourself for an illness that you cannot control.
Talk therapy and support groups with other caregivers in similar situations can help.
You also should make time to get regular medical checkups, exercise and a break from your loved one to recharge.

clueweb22-en0017-75-09634.point_content: Caregivers should seek prompt psychiatric attention if suffering from severe symptoms such as poor sleep, weight loss, loss of energy and interest, intense guilt and even suicidal or homicidal thinking.
spans: And if you're suffering from severe symptoms such as poor sleep, weight loss, loss of energy and interest, intense guilt and even suicidal or homicidal thinking, seek prompt psychiatric attention.

clueweb22-en0017-75-09634.point_content: There are three basic steps to address abusive behavior from a loved one with dementia: clarify the diagnosis, determine the cause of the abusive behavior, and treatment.
spans: But you also need to get to the root of the abuse, which can often be reversed or diminished with treatment. There are three basic steps that can turn the tide here.
1. Clarify the diagnosis
2. Determine the cause of the abusive behavior
3. Treatment

clueweb22-en0017-75-09634.point_content: Encourage a comprehensive evaluation to clarify diagnosis including physical, neurological exam, mental status exam and brain scan to rule out other causes.
spans: If you're concerned, it's important that you encourage your loved one to have a comprehensive evaluation that includes, among other tests, a physical and neurological exam, a mental status exam and a brain scan. The physician will want to rule out the many other issues than can cause a change in cognition and behavior — it's not always Alzheimer's.

clueweb22-en0017-75-09634.point_content: A geriatric psychiatrist can help understand causes of abusive behavior which include denial, depression, delusions and disinhibition.
spans: A geriatric psychiatrist or other clinician who has specific training in both mental health and neurocognitive disorders can help you understand why your loved one is suddenly cruel or angry.
The four most likely causes can be summarized by four D's: denial, depression, delusions and disinhibition.

clueweb22-en0017-75-09634.point_content: Denial involves being oblivious to cognitive changes and reacting with anger when impairment is suggested.
spans: Denial. In my practice I am less concerned about patients who tell me all they've forgotten than those like Ann who are oblivious to their cognitive changes and tend to get angry and erupt at anyone who suggests that they are impaired.

clueweb22-en0017-75-09634.point_content: Depression in neurocognitive disorders may manifest as irritability or anger and includes symptoms like insomnia, poor appetite, weight loss, lack of energy and physical aches.
spans: Depression. Depression is extremely common in the setting of neurocognitive disorders, sometimes as a result of knowing the diagnosis but more commonly due to pathologic changes in brain structure and chemistry.

Depression may manifest in irritability or anger instead of sadness, and is accompanied by symptoms such as insomnia, poor appetite and weight loss, lack of energy and interest, and physical aches and pains.

clueweb22-en0017-75-09634.point_content: Delusions involve false but fixed beliefs often causing paranoia or jealousy leading to fear and anger.
spans: Delusions. These are defined as false but fixed or deeply held beliefs, and more than half of people with Alzheimer's and other neurocognitive disorders tend to have them at some point.
Delusions often involve paranoia (they might believe that someone is trying to harm or steal from them) or jealousy (accusing one's partner or spouse of having an affair, for instance).
Delusional beliefs cannot be altered by logical reasoning or argument, and can lead to intense fear and anger.

clueweb22-en0017-75-09634.point_content: Disinhibition is characterized by inappropriate or strange behaviors including verbally abusive comments and is seen in certain dementias.
spans: Disinhibition. Characterized by inappropriate, uncharacteristic or strange behaviors, disinhibition is seen in early stages of frontotemporal dementia and in later stages of Alzheimer's.
In addition to verbally abusive or inappropriate comments, it may include behaviors that seem out of control, crude or embarrassing.

clueweb22-en0017-75-09634.point_content: Treatment depends on cause: supportive relationship for denial, antidepressants and therapy for depression, antipsychotics for delusions, and medications for disinhibition.
spans: Once the doctor has a hypothesis of what may be driving the verbal abuse, a relevant treatment plan can be devised.
Denial is difficult to address but does not always require confronting the person with the diagnosis.
Instead, the doctor needs to build a supportive relationship around issues that the afflicted person is concerned about, such as poor sleep or nervousness.
Depression can be successfully treated with both antidepressant medication and various forms of talk therapy.
Delusions often require antipsychotic medications, while disinhibition may respond to certain medications that temper the lack of brain control.

clueweb22-en0017-75-09634.point_content: Caregivers can learn strategies to emotionally distance themselves from abusive behavior, find support and get respite care.
spans: Caregivers can learn strategies to distance themselves from it emotionally, find support and get respite care.

clueweb22-en0040-80-13754.point_content: Caregivers can receive emotional support from professional therapists, in-person and online support groups, and one-on-one discussions with friends and family.
spans: Caregivers can receive emotional support from professional therapists, in-person and online support groups, and one-on-one discussions with friends and family.

clueweb22-en0040-80-13754.point_content: Skilled therapists will help you process your feelings, learn to set boundaries, strengthen your problem-solving abilities, and improve communication with your care recipient and other family members.
spans: Skilled therapists will help you process your feelings, learn to set boundaries, strengthen your problem-solving abilities, and improve communication with your care recipient and other family members.

clueweb22-en0040-80-13754.point_content: The National Institute on Aging suggests that caregivers find someone they can talk with and truly vent to without judgment to help head off feelings of isolation and powerlessness.
spans: The National Institute on Aging suggests that caregivers find someone they can talk with and truly vent to without judgment. Being able to confide in someone often helps to head off feelings of isolation and powerlessness in overwhelmed caregivers.

clueweb22-en0040-80-13754.point_content: Those who receive regular emotional support are better equipped to prevent burnout, handle difficult care decisions and balance their own needs with those of their loved ones.
spans: Those who receive regular emotional support are better equipped to prevent burnout, handle difficult care decisions and balance their own needs with those of their loved ones.

clueweb22-en0040-80-13754.point_content: For those who cannot afford counseling, talking with an understanding friend or family member and joining a support group are two free ways of receiving vital encouragement, information and advice.
spans: For those who cannot afford counseling, talking with an understanding friend or family member and joining a support group are two free ways of receiving vital encouragement, information and advice.

clueweb22-en0035-39-05697.point_content: The treatment of and attitudes towards the individual are crucial for empowerment at this level, in that they can influence communication of needs, wishes and wants.
spans: The treatment of and attitudes towards the individual are crucial for empowerment at this level, in that they can influence communication of needs, wishes and wants.

clueweb22-en0035-39-05697.point_content: Establishment of a good therapeutic relationship is crucial, which requires being respectful, non-judgemental and avoiding making the person feel inadequate.
spans: In order to maintain self-esteem, trust and enable the person to feel comfortable to disclose their feelings, choices and wishes, the establishment of a good therapeutic relationship is crucial. In order to attain this, it is important to be respectful, non-judgemental and avoid making the person feel inadequate in any way.

clueweb22-en0035-39-05697.point_content: A willingness to share power with service users and accept their expertise is essential for a trusting, ‘equal’ relationship and to create an empowering environment.
spans: In addition, a willingness to share power with service users and accept their expertise is essential [22 ]. This is integral for a trusting, ‘equal’ relationship and to create an empowering environment.

clueweb22-en0035-39-05697.point_content: It is important for the individual to know and believe that their views will be taken on board and their choices and decisions respected, and for this to be explicitly communicated.
spans: It is important for the individual to know and believe that their views will be taken on board and their choices and decisions respected, and for this to be explicitly communicated, not only in written literature about the service but in person by mental health professionals.

clueweb22-en0035-39-05697.point_content: Mental health care professionals need to be willing to collaborate and work in partnership with mental health service users and put aside beliefs that the professional knows best.
spans: Mental health care professionals need to be willing to collaborate and work in partnership with mental health service users and put aside beliefs that the professional knows best [24 ].

clueweb22-en0035-39-05697.point_content: Listening to and taking on board the comments, views and wishes of individuals with mental illness are extremely important for correct diagnosis and treatment plan.
spans: Listening to and taking on board the comments, views and wishes of individuals with mental illness are extremely important. This is not only essential in order for the person to have influence and control over what is happening to them, but to establish the correct diagnosis and a treatment plan which meets their needs, and with which they are happy to co-operate with.

clueweb22-en0035-39-05697.point_content: It is important to encourage active involvement of the person with mental illness at all stages of contact, from consultation, through to diagnosis, treatment, and after care.
spans: It is important to encourage active involvement of the person with mental illness at all stages of contact, from consultation, through to diagnosis, treatment, and after care.

clueweb22-en0035-39-05697.point_content: People with mental illness should be provided with the information and support they need to understand and effectively self-manage their mental health.
spans: People with mental illness should be provided with the information and support they need to understand and effectively self-manage their mental health [27 ].

clueweb22-en0035-39-05697.point_content: The Recovery Model supports professionals seeing past the illness and supporting the person to move forward with their lives and achieve their goals.
spans: The Recovery Model points to the importance of building resilience. This model does not stipulate the need to eliminate the symptoms of mental illness and provide a complete cure, which may or may not be possible, but it is about professionals being able to see past the person’s illness and support them to move forward with their lives, achieve their goals and engage in things which are meaningful for them.

clueweb22-en0005-92-12270.point_content: Caregivers should pay attention to their own feelings and understand that a range of emotions such as guilt, shame, fear, anger, sadness, and love are normal when caring for someone with mental illness.
spans: Caring for someone with a mental illness is a complex and demanding role, and it is normal for carers to experience a range of feelings about it.

Typical emotions include: Guilt - You may feel responsible for the illness but no one is to blame. You may feel guilty about not wanting to be a carer, or perhaps think, "I'm not doing enough." Shame - The stigma around mental illness can cause embarrassment. You may worry about what others think. Fear - It is normal to fear for the person's future or to worry about what will happen to him or her if you can't cope. Anger/frustration - You may feel frustrated with being a carer, or angry that others don't pitch in. You may think, "My friend/relative doesn't appreciate what I do or what I have sacrificed for them." Sadness - You may grieve for the loss of the relationship as it was and the life you once knew. You may feel sad about the loss of opportunities and plans for both yourself and your friend/relative. Love - Your love for your friend/relative may deepen and you may feel very motivated to help.

clueweb22-en0005-92-12270.point_content: Caregivers should develop an understanding of the mental illness, including its features, treatment options, medications, and the mental health system.
spans: Develop an Understanding of What Is Happening
A mental illness, like physical illness, is treatable. Learning about mental illness may ease fears about the unknown or unfamiliar. It is important to find out about: The features of the illness
Treatment options These may include medication, cognitive behavioral therapy, counseling, group programs, self-help approaches, stress management, etc.
Medications and their side effects A doctor or pharmacist will be able to help.
Understanding the mental health system The first step is to see a family doctor, psychologist or psychiatrist. To see a psychiatrist, many insurance companies require you to get a referral from a GP.

clueweb22-en0005-92-12270.point_content: Good communication is essential; caregivers should use non-verbal communication effectively and learn new ways of communicating, including listening skills, reflecting meaning, and sharing feelings non-confrontationally.
spans: Develop Good Communication
Non-verbal communication Communication is more than what we say. We also communicate in ways that are non-verbal.
Listening skills - Listening to what a person is saying without interrupting can be difficult, especially when you disagree with what is said, but if you do this, you are more likely to be heard too.
Reflecting meaning - You can show you understand someone by reflecting his or her feelings and the reasons for them.

Sharing your feelings in a non-confrontational way - Carers often feel that everything revolves around the person with the illness. But carers have a right to express their feelings too. To share your feelings in a non-confrontational way use 'I' statements ("I feel upset and worried when you...") rather than 'You' statements ("You make me so angry when you...").

clueweb22-en0005-92-12270.point_content: Caregivers should plan for problem behaviors by setting boundaries and working with the person and professionals to find solutions.
spans: Plan for Problem Behaviors
A person with a mental illness is still responsible for his or her actions. You might need to agree on what is and is not acceptable behavior.

You may need to decide how to approach these issues. Be aware of your own personal boundaries and discuss the situation with your friend or relative. Work together on a solution. If the agreed solution is not working, talk to a doctor, case manager, or counselor about what you can do.

clueweb22-en0005-92-12270.point_content: Empower the person with mental illness by respecting their individuality and right to make decisions, recognizing their strengths and difficulties.
spans: Empowering the person It is important to relate to your friend or relative as an individual, not just in terms of his or her illness.
He or she has the right to make decisions, including decisions about treatments.
Recognize the difficulty of your friend's/relative's situation. Acknowledging the person's strength and ability to face such situations can help minimize his or her sense of powerlessness.

clueweb22-en0005-92-12270.point_content: Caregivers must take time for themselves, ensuring self-care through breaks, health maintenance, support, and planning.
spans: Take Time for Yourself
Taking breaks - Recognize your limits - no one can be a carer every minute of every day. Make sure you go out and continue doing activities you enjoy.
Health - Maintaining good health is the best way to withstand stress.
Support - Having a friend or someone you can talk to about what you are experiencing, without judgment, is important.
Planning - Planning ahead can make things more manageable. Include the person you care for in the planning process.

clueweb22-en0005-92-12270.point_content: Caregivers should be vigilant for worsening symptoms or suicidal behavior and seek help promptly.
spans: What if things are getting worse? As a carer, you are in a good position to notice changes in the person's condition.

At times your friend or relative may feel suicidal.
